summary.seg: This manuscript, probably produced in the mid-17th century, contains part of a Commentary on the Psalms. The authorship of this commentary is not definitely established, but is generally attributed to the 5th-century priest Hesychios of Jerusalem. This work is the longest of three commentaries on the Psalms attributed to Hesychios, and has also commonly been erroneously attributed to John Chrysostom. Its content is most frequently attested in excerpts appearing in catenae and attributed to an undifferentiated "Hesychios". Manuscripts in which it appear as continuous text each contain only a portion of the work.

The portion found here, comprising the commentaries to Psalms 77-107 and 118, survives in only one medieval copy, Oxford, Bodleian Library, MS Roe 13, dating to 1284/5, from which this was copied. In the Bodleian manuscript, the individual Psalm commentaries of Hesychios are interspersed with those of John Chrysostom on Psalms 108-117 and 119-150 to create a continuous sequence, but here those of Hesychios have been singled out.

A number of supporting materials have subsequently been appended to the main text on additional folios, including a prologue to the Psalms, also by Hesychios and copied from another Oxford manuscript (Oxford, Bodleian Library, MS Auct. D.4.1), a Latin translation of the Psalms covered in the commentary, some line-by-line comments and notes on other Biblical texts.

The manuscript was owned by classical scholar Meric Casaubon, son of Isaac Casaubon, Isaac, 1559-1614 , and was bought for the University Library in the sale of his effects after his death in 1671. It is thus connected with a second manuscript of this text in the Library, MS Ff.3.2, which was also copied from the same exemplar, also owned by Casaubon and acquired by the Library at the same time. Among the additional materials are notes by Casaubon (i recto) in which he attributes the commentary to Hesychius, and copies a note on its authorship by Augustine Lindsell, previous owner of the other copy.

supportDesc.foliation: ff. 1-8, 12-13, 19-31 are incompletely foliated with the numbers 1-8, 12-13, 19-31, in brown ink, in Arabic numerals, recto, upper right.

ff. [a], i-vii, 9-11, 14-18, 32-65, [b] are foliated with the numbers [a] + i-vii + 9-11, 14-18, 32-54 + 55-65 + [b], in pencil, in Arabic and Roman numerals, recto, upper right, filling the gaps in the previous foliation.
Occasional folios are foliated in pencil, in Arabic numerals, recto, lower right, in a different sequence which includes ff. iii-vii within the main sequence, with errors.
supportDesc.condition: The edges are worn, and there are occasional small stains.

binding.p: 18th-century binding with brown full leather covering over couched-laminate boards, reused from a previous binding, with printed waste pastedowns (from a copy of the Decretum by Gratian). A thick modern brown folio has been stuck onto each of the outermost endleaves. There is decorative blind tooling on the boards, and the classmark is tooled in blind on labels and Hesychius M.S. in gold on a red leather label on the spine.
binding.condition: The spine has been rebacked. Both outer joints are partially split, and some of the leather covering has been lost from the head and tail of the spine.

history.provenance: Owned by Meric Cassaubon Casaubon, MÃ©ric, 1599-1671 (1599-1671).
history.acquisition: Bought for the University Library by Thomas Gale Gale, Thomas, 1635?-1702 after Cassaubon's death from the sale of his effects, with money from the bequest of John Hacket Hacket, John, 1592-1670 (1592-1670), Bishop of Lichfield and Coventry.

availability.p: Entry to read in the Library is permitted only on presentation of a valid reader's card. For information on eligibility and admissions procedures, see Joining the Library). For further information on the availability of the manuscript, please contact the Manuscripts Reading Room.

note.locus: ff. vi verso-vii verso are blank.

support.material: ff. ii-vii Western paper, folded in folio. Watermark: Horse ( 43 20 ) in the centre of the folio.

layoutDesc.layout:
ff. iii recto-iv recto A single column of 61-62 lines.
305 145
Single vertical lines defining the left and right margins, ruled in hardpoint.

ff. v recto-vi recto A single column of 48-54 lines.
305 135
Single vertical lines defining the left and right margins, ruled in hardpoint.

handDesc.handNote: f. ii recto, notes to ff. iii recto-iv recto were written by Meric Casaubon (Hand A).

handNote.p: ff. iii recto-vi recto were copied by Hand B. Greek text in a mixed minuscule script, slanting to the right, in brown ink, with modest variation in letter size.

There are no syllabic abbreviations or superscript word endings. Breathings are round and mute iota is subscript, appearing as a dot rather than a line. The use of the double dot is functional only, and nomina sacra are uncontracted.
The modern eta, modern nu and sigma telikon are present. There is very little use of ligatures.
Punctuation used includes the lower, middle and upper points and lower comma.

physDesc.additions: Meric Casaubon has added annotations to ff. iii recto-iv recto, and another hand to f. v recto.

history.origin: This part has been added at some point between 1628 and 1671, between the copying of the main body of the manuscript (Part III) and the death of Meric Casaubon in 1671.

msItem.title: Notes on the Greek text of the Old Testament
msItem.note: f. 54r is blank; f. 54v is blank apart from a note.

support.material: ff. 1-30 Western paper, folded in folio. Watermark: Coat of arms (crook) ( 120 75 ) in the centre of the folio, similar to Briquet 1383. This example is dated to 1585-1607.
ff. 31-54 Western paper, folded in folio. Watermark: Coat of arms (crook) ( 120 75 ) in the centre of the folio, similar to Briquet 1370. This example is dated to 1595-1605.

collation.p: The main body of the manuscript consists of 9 quires, of which one is a binion, one a quaternion, and the rest are ternia.

layoutDesc.layout:
ff. 1r-49r A single column of 48-80 lines. 301-312 160-170
Single vertical lines defining the left and right margins, ruled in hardpoint.

ff. 51r-53v A single column of 48-62 lines. 315 150
Single vertical lines defining the left and right margins, ruled in hardpoint.

handNote.p: ff. 1r-49r were copied by Hand C in a mixed minuscule script, slanting to the right, in brown ink, with modest variation in letter size.

Syllabic abbreviations appear throughout the line, while there is no superscription of word endings. Breathings are round and mute iota is subscript, appearing as a dot rather than a line. The use of the double dot is functional only, and nomina sacra are uncontracted. Accents are sometimes joined to letters.

The modern eta, modern nu and sigma telikon and loop epsilon are present, and there are inclusions of letters within omicron. There is a distinctive form of tau-omega-nu ligature, with an elevated omega joined to the foot of a tilted minuscule nu with a shortened descender.
Punctuation used includes the lower, middle and upper points, lower comma and question mark.

handDesc.handNote: ff. 51r-54v, notes to ff. 1r-49r were copied by Hand B.

physDesc.additions: The copyist of the main text, Hand C, has added marginal corrections, and bibliographical references in Latin; further bibliographical references and notes have been added by Hand B. There are later marginal annotations in Greek and Latin, in pencil.

history.origin: The watermark of the paper suggests production in the late 16th or early 17th century. However, the use of Latin in the copyist's notes suggests that it was produced in western Europe, and hence presumably in England England after the return of Sir Thomas Roe Roe, Thomas, Sir, 1581?-1644 with the Greek manuscripts he had acquired, including this manuscript's exemplar, Bodleian Library, MS Roe 13, in 1628. Combined with its ownership by Meric Casaubon, this would date its production to 1628-1671.

msItem.title: Psalms 77-106, 118
msItem.note: ff. 62v-63r, 64v, 65r-65v are blank. f. 64r is blank apart from a note. f. 64v is blank apart from a few notes giving references to the text.
